passages.text: India | Consumer Finance
Growth and Asset Quality Headwinds; Expect Better Trends in 2H

Loan demand stays subdued. GST rationalization can lift demand in select segments & aid the small truck operators, but price deflation will negative for disbursements and LTV. Stress has increased across segments incl. MSME due to slowing macro; tariffs can increase stress in select pockets. Pick up in eco- activity & lower rates should ease the pressure in 2H. NIMs should expand & cushion earnings. Top picks remain BAF, CIFC & SHFL; MUTH is a defensive play.

Loan demand stays dull; optimism around improvement in 2H. Loan demand has been subdued. July freight rates are steady MoM and up \(6\%\) YoY (Shriram Mobility Bulletin), but CV operators indicate pressure on rates and margins. Tractor registration have been good (+32% YTD) signaling better rural sentiment on good monsoon. The proposed GST cut can lift demand especially for 2W and PV. Proposed cut for CVs (28% to 18%) can improve affordability of new CVs, but price deflation will be a drag on disbursement value. Anticipation of the GST cut could push disbursements from 2Q to 3Q. In housing, demand has been tepid, but affordable HFCs & select HFCs indicated better disbursement run rate during 2Q YTD vs. 1Q avg YTD.

Smaller truck operators may benefit from GST rationalization. Government may rationalize GST for goods and transport agencies (GTA) to \(5\%\) with no input tax credit (ITC). If implemented, it can reduce the disadvantage small truck operators have vs. larger GTAs. Currently, GTAs have option of a) \(5\%\) GST paid by customer with no ITC or b) \(12\%\) GST paid by operator with ITC. Large truck operators pay \(12\%\) GST, but can set of ITC of GST paid on trucks, spares; smaller truck operators (main segment for NBFCs) prefer \(5\%\) GST (lower compliance burden) and cannot claim ITC.

Asset quality risks in MSME and from trade tariffs: Stress has increased in most segments in 1Q due to slowing economy & 2Q trends should be similar. Price deflation due to GST cut is negative for LTV of auto NBFCs. Stress in MSME has increased esp in smaller ticket MSME BL. Per TransUnion CIBIL, MSME business loans grew \(29\%\) CAGR in last 5 years and delinquencies have increased in smaller ticket BL. 90- 720 DPD for loans < Rs1mn has increased by 70bps YoY and vintage delinquency has increased too. We see some AQ risks in retail & MSME esp. in select pockets due to tariffs. Exports in affected sector like textile and gems account for US \(19 - 20bn\) of exports and it employs c. \(50mn+\) people. Potential uptick in economic activity & freight demand post monsoon, stronger rural cash flows and lower rates can ease pressure in 2H.

Margin improvement 2Q onward: Margins in 1Q were rangebound and should start to improve 2Q onwards esp for fixed rate lenders (auto NBFCs, cards, gold NBFCs) with higher EBLR liabilities. Spreads at AHFCs should also improve as yields are stickier vs. prime housing loans. With banks cutting home loan rates by \(\sim 100\) bps from peak, NIMs at bond- funded HFCs like LICHF may compress with a lag, but near- term spreads will be cushioned by faster bank borrowing repricing (EBLR- linked).

Growth and AQ headwinds, but NIM tailwind; Valuations appear reasonable: Sector faces near term growth and asset quality headwinds, but NIM expansion can cushion the pressure on earnings. Sector valuations are reasonable near 10 year average P/B. We prefer select diversified NBFCs like BAF given its ability to toggle across segments and as pressure in MSME BL (12% of AUM) is not as high as feared. At CIFC, soft demand and AQ trends will weigh on stock price near term, but these should offer attractive entry points esp given healthy
fundamentals and multiple levers on 12 month basis. At SHFL, valuations at 1.6x FY1BV seems attractive.
Exhibit 1 - Avg round trip rentals of routes (for 18t payload- Rs'000) for metro cities like Mumbai, Chennai, Kolkata and Delhi have been stable/positive for last 6 months

Large truck operators pay \(12\%\) GST under forward charge and use it to set off GST paid on trucks. This effectively reduces truck acqn costs. Smaller truck operators pay \(5\%\) GST with out ITC

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus \(20\%\) or less within a 12- month period.
NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a \(15\%\) stop loss, and the remainder will have a \(20\%\) stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
